7: my postings related to the classes I am currently

5: Mathematical Statistics I, II (4 units each)
6: Theory of point and interval estimation and hypothesis testing, from the Neyman-Pearson point of view. May in─────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────

Theory of point and interval estimation and hypothesis testing, from the Neyman-Pearson point of view. May include decision theory, non-parametric inference, sequential analysis, multivariate analysis,
7: robustness, Bayesian methods, computer intensive methods. Cross-listed with MATH 6501, 6502. Prerequisites: MATH 3300, STAT 3402.

5: Mathematical Statistics I, II (4 units each)
6: Theory of point and interval estimation and hypothesis testing, from the Neyman-Pearson point of view. May in─────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────

Theory of point and interval estimation and hypothesis testing, from the Neyman-Pearson point of view. May include decision theory, non-parametric inference, sequential analysis, multivariate analysis,
7: robustness, Bayesian methods, computer intensive methods. Cross-listed with MATH 6501, 6502. Prerequisites: MATH 3300, STAT 3402.

5: The main topics to be covered in the 6501 and 6502 sequence are Limit Theorems, Estimation, Hypothesis Testing, Bootstrapping, and Bayesian Estimation and Inference.  Before we engage in the study of these
6: topics we will review some probability and statistics topics, such as random variables and probability simulation.
8: We will use the R statistical language to demonstrate and apply many of the ideas in the course. R code will be given in class and you will be given assignments related to these examples.
